qas.question: Besides the thermomechanical process, what is a process used in pulping?
What is the main ingredient in the groundwood process?
What strength of paper is produced by mechanical pulps?
In which process is wood chipped and fed into small steam heated refiners?
In which process are the chips converted to fibers between three steel discs?
What is fed into mechanical pulps during the groundwood process?
Where are debarked logs fed into during the TMP process?
What are debarked logs pressed against to make pulp?
Besides the thermomechanical process, what is a process not used in pulping?
What is not the main ingredient in the groundwood process?
What strength of wood is produced by mechanical pulps?

context: There are two major mechanical pulps, the thermomechanical one (TMP) and <a0_0>groundwood pulp<a0_0/> (GW). In the <b3_0><b4_0>TMP<b4_0/><b3_0/> process, wood is chipped and then fed into large steam heated refiners, where the chips are squeezed and converted to fibres between two steel discs. In the <b8_0>groundwood<b8_0/> process, <a1_0><b5_0><b9_0>debarked logs<b9_0/><b5_0/><a1_0/> are fed into <b6_0>grinders<b6_0/> where they are pressed against <b7_0>rotating stones<b7_0/> to be made into fibres. Mechanical pulping does not remove the lignin, so the yield is very high, >95%, however it causes the paper thus produced to turn yellow and become brittle over time. Mechanical pulps have rather short fibres, thus producing <a2_0><b10_0>weak<b10_0/><a2_0/> paper. Although large amounts of electrical energy are required to produce mechanical pulp, it costs less than the chemical kind.
